Attach the mount to a 2020 extrusion and attach the Arduino Mega with zip ties. Attach the enclosure to the PICA board itself with M3 8mm hex screws and hex nut. Wires go in large circular hole. Credit goes to mjrice who designed the original pieces and the Wilson II.

description.text:
This design is used to mount 3/4" conduit legs to the ends of a FreeMo module for model trains. I have successfully printed this object and have them installed on my modules for further durability testing. The mounting slots are sized for #8 sheet metal screws. The bosses are meant to be drilled and tapped 10-24 for a thumbscrew to retain the leg while moving the module.
All parts have been designed to print without support
The upper part of the leg is 3/4" EMT conduit 30" long
The lower part of the leg is 1/2" EMT conduit 20" long
This will make a leg that will adjust from about 40" railhead height for NTrak to the 50" FreeMo height.
The "Leg End" parts should be printed with high infill for strength, as they are press fit (hammer in) to the inside of the 1/2" conduit. You will need to use a tap to thread the hole in the appropriate sized part for a 1/4" (Leg End_250) or 5/16" (Leg End_312) x 3" long carriage bolt.
The "Leg foot" parts are designed to fit 1/4" or 5/16" carriage bolts and should be printed in a flexible (or semi flex) material to protect floors from the bare bolt head. The "Leg foot cap" should be printed in a rigid material and will engage the square feature of the carriage bolt for fine height adjustment.
You will also need some 1/4" hardware for the pinch clamp on the "Leg pinch joint" part. This is another part that should be printed with high infill for strength. Use care when tightening the pinch bolt - it doesn't take a whole lot of force to lock the leg into position!
04-22-2017 All parts redrawn in Fusion 360 - Much easier to make revisions than TinkerCAD!
revisions:
Leg pocket - added "vee" groove opposite thumbscrew hole for even better alignment of leg when clamped.
Leg end-312x500 & Leg stabiliz-500 - removed part of flange to allow changing print orientation for better strength - eliminate "popping off" the flange when driving it into the conduit.
Leg end-312x750 - part added to allow fixed length legs using only 3/4" EMT conduit.
Leg pinch joint - reduced the size/depth of the spot face to increase strength in the pinch bolt "ear" - use 1/4-20 panhead screws instead of bolts for proper fit.
11-04-2017 Added pocket design for 1/2" conduit legs - "half inch.stl"

author: BuddyC

description.text:
This is an eyeball with left/right, and up/down manual controls.
It uses a ball and socket joint that snaps together to allow eye movement within a socket. Strings are attached to the inside of the eye from within the control box and through the neck which allow you to make the eyeball look around by turning the knobs. Video: http://youtu.be/Emg2zwOq7Ck

All parts are printed without supports if you orient them properly.
Neck parts all have a flat end with button holes. Make sure that end is flat on the build surface.
Print the socket and eyeball with the open end facing up. I used a scaling factor of 500% and printed with PLA on a Replicator 2 at 0.15mm resolution.
Besides the printed parts you will need some good, thin string and some super glue. Here are the assembly instructions (see photos for reference). Notes: the string can be tricky to handle so you might want to get a third hand to help. You may also have to shave or sand the stems of the eyelets slightly so they fit into the rectangular holes in the eyeball fairly easily.
The ball and socket snap fits between the eyeball and socket.
This can only be done once. You will never get them apart once they are together without breaking it! 1) Cut 4 pieces of string about 1.5 to 2 ft long
2) Thread the 4 pieces of string through each of the 4 "button" holes on the long neck. The flat part with the button holes will be the bottom.
3) Continue threading through the middle neck piece and to the end neck piece that connects to the eye socket.
It is important to not let the string cross or get twisted. Try to orient the button holes so there is a top, bottom, left and right hole. Keep them aligned and pay attention to how the neck bends.
4) Continue threading through the eye socket.
5) Carefully glue these pieces together in the right orientation without the strings crossing each other, being careful not to get any glue on the string. Once glued I recommend that you tape the bottom end of the strings so they can't accidentally pull through the holes. If any do pull through then you'll have to tear it apart and start again.
6) Thread each string through a small eyelet and tie a big enough knot in the end to stop it from popping back through the hole (use a dab of glue on the knot to keep it snug on the eyelet).
7) Push the eyelet only partially through each hole on the inside of the eyeball. Pay really close attention to the order of these eyelets so again the strings are in the right order. Triple check them as it is so easy to get it wrong! Remembering that the inside of the eyeball will connect to socket with the top, bottom, left and right eyelets oriented correctly.
8) Once you are triple sure of the orientation and connections put a little dab of glue on each eyelet and push it all the way through the hole. Do this for all four.
9) Use nail clippers and snip off the stems of the eyelets that stick through the eyeball.
10) Here's the critical, nerve-racking part where you snap the eyeball into the socket. You need to make sure the eyeball is in the right orientation and the strings are pulled so that they are fairly straight and NOT crossing, or caught in the ball socket. Once you know the ball is mated to the socket, snap them together nice and firmly. You might want to shake it to make sure nothing broke.
11) Glue the neck onto the box top with the strings through the bottom.
12) Arrange the knobs and levers so that they are oriented 45 degrees as shown in the picture.
13) Tape the eyeball still so it is centred and not moving around.
14) Pull the strings so there is no play in them and guide them through the big eyelets to the appropriate levers (top and bottom go to one lever, while left and right go to the other).
15) Thread through the holes in the levers and tie the strings.
16) Trim the strings, glue the knobs on, glue (or screw) the box bottom on and you are done!

remixed_from.author: piercet
remixed_from.title: Wider Light Bars and Brackets for Taz or other Large Bed Printers

description.text:
This project is an upgrade to my previous lightbar work. It extends the edges of the lightbar to make for more comfortable printing with a printer at eye level, adds 2 new sizes (200mm and 100mm) for use with smaller print beds and printers, introduces a new fully enclosed lightbar mount for use with these extrusion slot covers (http://www.mcmaster.com/#catalog/122/1939/=14feq5y) to run wires from the lightbar to the frame edges fully concealed, and also adds my corner reinforcement covers, which are designed for use with a Taz, but should fit almost any square 20mm extrusion design corners to aid in wire routing from the extrusions to the control box area.

Update 1: New 4.5 variant endcaps and mounts are larger for routing wires easier.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.5mm nozzle, 0.3mm layer heights

Infill:

85%

Notes:

To print the longest bar you will need a Taz or similar sized printer, and will need to print it diagonally on the bed.

Instructions

  1. Insert the slot covers (http://www.mcmaster.com/#catalog/122/1939/=14feq5y) into the t-slot that will become your cable run. Typically this will be the top bar and at least one of the side bars. You may wish to purchase extra to install it in the opposite side for asthetic reasons even if you do not intend to run wires in that side.

  2. Determine where the lightbar end mounts will go, and punch a hole large enough to pass the positive and negitive wire into the surface of the slot cover at that point.

  3. print all parts.

  4. Begin assembly of the lightbar. You will want a 12 or 24v 5mm wide "waterproof" light strip. Not so much for any supposed water resistance, but because the waterproof ones have their own lens built in basically. You will need to drill a hole in the center of the endcap that you will route the wires through (a 1/8" drillbit or equivelent should fit) .

  5. Adhere the light strip to the light bar, feed the wires out through the endcap and then press both endcaps onto the light bar
  6. Now carefully feed the wires through the enclosed mounting ends. You should end up with wire prodruding out of the section that will be in contact with the extrusion slot cover with a hole in it.
  7. Feed the wire through that hole, and over to the corner.
  8. optional - Install one of the corner slot cover pieces. This will give you enough room to conceal wire quick disconnects and pass the wire from the top extrusion into another extrusion slot cover on the side, and then down into the control box.

title: Smart Phone Wall Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A fully 3D printed articulated wall mount for your smart phone.

Chose the Phone_Bracket file which corresponds the best with your total width (including any hull etc.)

I'm using Phone_Bracket_750 for my LG G4 since it's about 75mm wide.

I don't have the time right now to revise it to be easily customizeable so I included different versions ranging from 65mm up to 80mm of width in 2.5mm step size.

With the clamping screw it has a adaptability of around 8 mm.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

10%

Notes:

I suggest 3 perimeters, no support and 20% infill for the wall mount and bolts and 10 % infill for the rest.

You can add supports to the horizontal smooth 10 mm bore holes if you want to, the threads have lots of tolerance and should do fine without, low layer height helps with the overhangs.
Assemble as seen in the picture - tighten the bolts to reduce / stiffen the movability.

Made with OpenSCAD, I'll propably make it customizeable if I get some free time and there is demand for it.

Includes polyScrewThread_r1.scad by aubenc:

description.text:
Like many others I was frustrated that I couldn't get these to fit because their inner and outer diameter were pretty much the same. So I imported the stl into SketchUp and used the rough measurements to draw another one. I beveled the inner edge so supports aren't required anymore.

I've printed these at 0.3mm on a 0.4mm nozzle with 10% infill in PLA and they fit really well. Some other plastics might need a different tolerance, so I'll upload the SketchUp file with some instructions on how to change the tolerance very soon.

11/4/2016: I've updated the stud ornaments also by adding a beveled inner edge and outer lip. Still modifying the clearances so they might not be perfect yet.

description.text:
I designed this crumbling throne on a raised dais to be compatible with my True Tiles and OpenForge dungeon pieces. This piece has three iterations, a simple raised dais, a crumbling raised dais with moss or dirt spots modeled on, and a version of the crumbling dais with a broken throne.

The raised dais alone is a great way to bring attention to a chest, statue, or other item. The ruined throne is great for playing host to a dungeon-dwelling humanoid enemy. The intact dais can also double as a stage for your tavern bards. Whatever you use the pieces for, have fun and please post your paint jobs to inspire others.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1

Infill:

20%

Notes:

This piece was printed with matterhackers 3.00mm PLA filament.

As always, I recommend that you start with a light sanding around the edges of the piece and then lay down a black base coat. After that, just have fun. The sample shown was painted with Vallejo Model Colors and shaded with Citadel Nuln Oil, I do not recommend a clear coat, but if you feel the need to lay one down I'd recommend Testors Dullcote.

I mixed my own gray gradient in three coats for this piece. The first coat was a very dark grey, followed by a lighter brushing of medium grey, followed again by a dry brushing of light grey and then highlighted with white. The moss is done in intermediate green, lime green, and desert camouflage. I used cerulean for the gem.

author: babali

print_settings.Resolution:: 300 micron for bases, 100 micron for clickable transparent parts

title: FMC (Flight Management Computer) for Boeing 737 lightable Buttons for thing 774564

description.text:
Updated 11/28/2017

  • Added the png file for the buttons
  • Added Quantities to print

    These buttons are for the design for the FMC (FlightManagementComputer) for Boeing 737NG by User0180 (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:774564).

All bases can be printed by PLA or ABS or PETG or any other material you prefer which is rigid at a slow speed (40-50 mm/sec). Be sure that material is not transparent preferably black. 300 micron is enough.

Transperant inside parts can be printed by any transparent filament like PETG Natural. These needs to be transperant to transfer the led light. Print with 100 micron.

Letters can be printed on a transparency film for inkjet. And then cut them with a scissor or very sharp knife and glue then on transparent parts.

Use a fast drying clear glue (I use Sico Met 101 from Henkel). (Now obsolete)
Update: Now I use 3M 468MP double sided very thin tape which is very fast and clean to stick the letters on the inserts.

Parts are clickable into the base, so you can anytime detach them and change the film on it. You do not need to glue them into the base.

Letters.png file is an Adobe Fireworks file, which is a vector design. If you have similar software you can play on the design.

So as a summary:

  1. Print bases with a dark color non-transparent filament
  2. Print inserts parts with a transparent filament
  3. Print the letters.png on a transparency film for an inkjet printer and cut
  4. Glue the letters on relevant transparent clickable parts and click them into the bases.

That's it. With a 3 mm led under them they will shine at night.

If anybody is interested in the design of buttons I use Cubify invent and I can share my design if you leave a comment.

UPDATE: I finally completed the all rectangle ones, for the circle ones I need to find a safe way to cut the letters properly.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2.1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

title: Paracord spool tool holder with butane lighter holder and razor blade
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a convenient spool holder for 550 paracord, with some clever features, inspired by the Spool Tool (TM) product available from online retailers. This one is considerably cheaper! Print out as many as you need.

Features:

  • Integrated Bic mini butane lighter clip: Used for melting the ends, keeps them from fraying
  • Integrated razor blade with safety guard: Used to cleanly cut the paracord without fumbling for your knife or scissors
  • Sixteen stay-put clips: Cutouts keep the paracord from falling off the spool
  • Dimensions: 150mm(6") x 88mm (3.5") x 3mm (1/8")
  • Capacity: Holds 100 feet of paracord
  • Made in (insert your country name here)

Build Instructions

  • Gather up a Bic Mini butane lighter, a square razor blade, some 550 paracord, 4x M2.5 nuts, 4x M2.5 x 4mm flat-head philips-drive machine screws, a hot glue gun, a philips screwdriver, and approximately 10 meters of PLA or ABS filament.
  • Print from the STL. Use supports when printing
  • Use hot glue to secure the razor blade in place, on the large piece. There is a groove for the reinforced part of the blade, with a bit of room for adjustment.
  • Quickly hot glue the top cover in place, making sure to line up both pieces so that the holes line up. Also try not to get any hot glue into the screw holes.
  • Stick the sandwiched assembly into a panavise or just use your hands to apply pressure. Wait for the glue t dry.
  • Insert the M2.5 screws and the nuts into the nut traps. Screw tight. NOTE: The screws are optional if you're using decent-quality high-temp hot glue, or some other decent adhesive.
  • The lighter should clip right into the spool holder.
  • Wrap the paracord, starting the first end in one of the sixteen clips. Finally, clip the loose end into another of the sixteen clips.

title: Geeetech Prusa i3 Bed Levelling Corner Bracket M3 Nut

description.text:
I was so sick of both hands are needed, one for holding wing nuts and one for tightening the screw while levelling the bed.
I created this piece so that the brackets won't turn around, I only need to turn the screw for adjusting the bed. it made my life so much easier.

Requirements and instructions

4x M3 nuts. This model's M3 nut cut-out has pretty tight tolerance. I recommend to use pressure fit method. Keep the nuts in a freezer. When brackets are done printing, keep the bed heated. While the parts are still warm, push the frozen nuts in the cut-out.

title: Geeetech Prusa i3 Adjustable Feet & Brackets

description.text:
For levelling Geeetech Prusa i3. The front bracket folk is wider than the front&back bracket because of my machine use 2 acrylic plates on the front. All of the bracket's folk has wider opening for adding the bicycle inner tube as a shock absorber.
You'll need 6x M6 nuts and bolts each, and bicycle inner tube (0.85 thick rubber, you can use something else if the thickness and material property is similar). The feet cap in the picture has rubber rings but these came off while I was levelling the bed.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

40 & 30%

Notes:

Support: need only for brackets.
Infill: Cap-40%, brackets-30%

Instruction

This model's M6 bolt head and nut cut-out has tight tolerance. I recommend to use pressure fit method.

  1. Keep the nuts and bolts in a freezer.
  2. When parts are done printing, leave them on the bed (remove the support from the brackets), keep the bed heated.
  3. While the parts are still warm, push the frozen nuts and bolts into the cut-out.
  4. Assemble feet and brackets together, tighten the feet to lowest.
  5. Cut the bicycle inner tube in about 30 to 35mm wide. wrap the acrylic plate where you put the bracket on and slide it inside the bracket's folk (see the pic below).

*When you level the machine, start adjusting only 4 feet, front and back. When they are levelled, adjust the 2 sides. You'll be pulling your hair out if you try to adjust all 6 feet at the same time.

title: Semi-Tube 'Muscle Trainer'
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Semi-Tube Slingshot Muscle Trainer

For slingshot shooting muscle strength is the key to achieve power AND precision.
So each day there should be a training session to build up and keep
the muscles to draw and pinch the ammo. But not everybody has the
opportunity to shoot real life ammo on daily base.

So I was thinking to have slingshot training session without emissions
(ammo AND noise) but the feeling of the 'real thing', fork lever force and ammo pinch.

And here it is:

  • One strip 12,5 cm Thera-Band fits around the single fork cone
  • A tight knot at the end mimics the ammo

(I prefer Thera-Band Black, the blue on the photo is for better contrast)

Of course you don't let go !!! Stretch and Relax as many times you want and can.
If the knot slips out of your grip it just hits the single 'fork' arm with a bang
but no pain and danger.

Just make a knot at one end and pull it tight (I recommend Talcum powder)
wrap the other end around the fork cone with 5 mm overlap and than wrap
a small office rubber closed loop with maximum force (about 4 to six times)

SAFETY: Wear safety glasses at any time. Rubber is unpredictable!

Have fun .... and muscle pain :-)

da Vinci 1.0

Yes

Yes

0.3 mm

30%

ABS

and the version 'Left' for dominant left handed

author: shanteschuler

title: D-Bot Add-On 40mm Sorbothane Vibration Dampener Foot Mount

description.text:
Note: After some use, I've decided the sorbothane feet I used in this, while they do a great job at reducing the hum emitted from my stepper motors and fans, are too soft and are probably rated for a weight the printer doesn't come close to reaching. The whole printer rocks around a bit, from the movement of the print head. I may remove these in favor of something more solid, but still vibration-dampening. - 10-20-16

Just something I threw together real quick to mount as an add-on for my D-Bot. The noise the printer makes is more tolerable than my previous printer, the Prusa i3 Rework, but I thought I would try to dampen the sound a little.

There is a small recess where the sound dampening feet go and I printed with no support material right on my print bed. This means where the feet are, the print is uneven, but the sorbothane is very soft so it conforms really well.

These are corner brackets intended to be mounted over the already installed bottom corner brackets for the D-Bot frame. I made them as add-ons instead of replacements for the corner brackets because I did not want to have to disassemble anything, especially if I found them to be ineffective in dampening the sound.

Unfortunately, after I installed these, I realized that the sorbothane feet I attached(they come with adhesive pads) are a little too soft, so the whole printer rocks side to side, although it is quieter.

A large source of the noise for my printer, I suspect, is the 84oz-in torque stepper motors I'm using.

As a solution, I'll be getting some firmer feet to test.

    It's not really a remix but rather a functional combination.
    It may be because I for whatever reason (to clean excessive coffee?) I got used to fill the coffee into the funnel separated from the water tank. So I need a stand for the bialetti funnel and a bigger funnel for easy filling.
    It is designed for the 2 cup Brikka funnel. I'm not sure how similar the funnels of other manufacturers / sizes / types are.
    Thoug I'm not sure if it's practical to combine I created this thing. As I'm waiting for some new nozzles I couldn't print it, yet. Some real pictures will follow afterwards.
    Note: Insert the Bialetti funnel with the lower seal.

description.text:
This is a simple tool for locking the vertical intake cam gear in place when doing a timing belt change on a Ducati 999. While this was designed for doing a belt change on a 2003 Ducati 999R, it may also fit for the 749/999/Testastretta engine series of motorcycles. I bought a commercial tool that had the wrong tooth pitch, so I figured I'd just design one myself.

I wanted something simple and non-marring, so printing this part out in PLA works perfectly for me. Plus...if you ever lose it, you just print a new one.

Tips:

  • There are lots of good YouTube videos on how to change belts on a Ducati.
  • Use an engine turning tool to adjust the cams slightly if needed to get this cam lock tool to align perfectly and lock the upper intake cam gear.
  • Be sure to fit the cam locking tool in place before removing the belt from the vertical cylinder or the intake cam will move.

description.text:
Select Mini 3D Printer Tool Bracket Holder - SD Card Holder

This repository contains an SD Card Holder for the Select Mini Tool Bracket Holder made by eburgess4 (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1688459).

Modifying the Design

All source materials were designed using OpenSCAD. Opening any of the .scad files in
this repo can be altered with OpenSCAD.

Once modifications are complete, OpenSCAD should be used to render and export the updated model as an .STL file

Slicing and Print Settings

All exported .STL files were sliced using Cura.

The following settings were used:

  • Quality
    • Layer Height: 0.1 mm
  • Shell
    • Wall Thickness: 0.8 mm
    • Top/Bottom Thickness: 0.8 mm
  • Infill
    • Density: 20.0 %
  • Material (Note: Used for PLA)
    • Printing Temperature: 195 C
    • Build Plate Temperature: 50 C
    • Diameter: 1.75mm
    • Flow: 100%
    • Enable Retraction: True
  • Speed
    • Print Speed: 60 mm/s
    • Travel Speed: 120 mm/s
  • Cooling
    • Enable Print Cooling: True
  • Support
    • Enable Support: True
    • Support Placement: Everywhere
  • Build Plate Adhesion
    • Build Plate Adhesion Type: Skirt

GitHub

https://github.com/rwaskiewicz/MpSelectMiniToolBracketSdCard

Credits

This design is a derivative of the Monoprice MP Select Mini Tool Bracket/Holder by eburgess4, available at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1688459 The original design is licensed under the Creative Commons - Attribution license. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/

This part needs a version 2.0, but it is operational. The tension on the belt pulls with enough force to angle the whole part (as seen in the picture).

For version 2.0:
-Rotate bearings to rotate on an axis parallel to the x axis instead of the z axis.
-Change mount part to accommodate the new bearing direction.

description.text: Abstract 3Man Award Sculpture
Using Shapeshifter.io: http://shapeshifter.io/#/share/MSAxIDIgMyAyLjkxIDEyIDIuMDEgMS4wNCAwIDAgMCAwLjUwIDAgMCAwLjUwIDAgMCAwLjUwIDAgMCAwIDAgMSAjZmNiZDc0IDIz

This is a puzzle piece that you can customize (change length, width, depth, mating ends, text, and more). Further customization instructions given once you click "Open in Customizer."

All dimensions are in millimeters, so you can design the pieces to be the exact length you need. To find out how long a dimension is in inches, take that value and divide it by 25.4. (Example: 76.2mm is how many inches? 76.2/25.4 = 3 inches)

The default settings will create a 3-inch-by-1.5-inch puzzle piece.

If you have any issues or find any flaws in this object, please let me know.

comments.text: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2558584 I designed this part for another printer design. Doing a beta right now for MP Maker Select, Wanhao Duplicator, and their clones. There's enormous criticism but if it aint broke don't fix it, once this is installed it definitely aint broke, you can look at my before and after. I will have this installed on my own machine soon but I'm extremely busy for another few days. Again, beta still.
comments.author: Gremble

comments.text: do you need smaller screws ?
comments.author: Charlo_10

comments.text: I didn't since bolts didn't poke to other side of anti-wobble, but if it does on yours, then yeah you need shorter ones.
comments.author: Charlo_10

comments.text:
These work great, lubricated the friction surfaces with a little Napa Sil-glyde. I did have to move the leadscrew couplers down a few mm on the z-motor shafts or the leadscrew nut bolt heads would hit them before z-home (i have my bed cranked down almost as tight as it'll go).
FLSun did well leaving the tops of the leadscrews free so that they could move around freely without dragging the x-axis around, with these decouplers and some plumb-couplers at the bottom there should be minimal horizontal forces acting on it.
comments.author: macelius

comments.text: Just installed these. Was kinda sceptical that two tiny brackets would help, but I'm genuinely impressed with how much better my prints look. Thanks a ton, XXCoder!
comments.author: DoctorBagPhD

comments.text: I'm considering upgrading mine with wax paper for even less friction between, and rubber band to keep those together better without actually coupling those together.
comments.author: DoctorBagPhD

comments.text: That sounds like it could be a good shout. I was planning on greasing mine up. Let me know how you get on?
comments.author: XXCoder

comments.text: I don't know yet. Double sided tape and some wax sheet on both contact surfaces maybe.
comments.author: DoctorBagPhD

comments.text: I used some Sil-glyde from Napa, but considering ordering some thin stick-on PTFE (Teflon) sheet, like you get for slider pads for gaming mice.
comments.author: XXCoder

comments.text: Yeah! It is pretty amazing. Especially if you constrain Z screws which make height control better but makes wobble much worse! This fixes that.
comments.author: DoctorBagPhD

comments.text:
Thank YOU soooo much ;) The wobble is completly gone. Thaaanks!!!
Btw. : I used m3x12 screws.
comments.author: MFOX

comments.text: No problem! :D
comments.author: MFOX

comments.text: So i dont use the leadscrew that was mounted into the orginal part anymore & screw it into your stl?
comments.author: Armin3322

comments.text: It's just bolt the leadscrew nut into this part, and this parts lifts or lowers, and X assembly will stay with it by gravity. If your leadscrew is wobbly this cancels the wobble, so prints are cleaner.
comments.author: Armin3322

comments.text: I installed it! Works great thank you! Do you use sth to cool your filament? i am looking for a mount for the fan..
comments.author: XXCoder

comments.text: sth? Right now my machine fan is at stock position unfortunately. Will eventually order more fans and connect it to proper fan PWM output so speed is controllable, and swap 40mm one with 30mm as that should be sufficient to keep top of hotend cool but not spray too much on print (for warp-sensitive prints)
comments.author: Armin3322

description.text:
BEHOLD!

The Ancient One has visited me on a dream (and prophetized by #CostumeChallenge) , and drove me to madness (of course).
After months of despair (an evening I guess), I dug on ancient books (and some Zbrush).
I've drawn the face of inextricable horror, a gaze of insanity, and a goatee of hideous tentacles (well tentacle-fingers from Tiger stores)

October, 25:

The dreams keep coming... They have been more and more daunting every day. Now, I can see the Ancient's face clearly (as clear coating), and even in the dark it's gaze is coming after me!

Printer:

Custom CoreXY

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

10

Notes:

This thing is better printed on two halves, mirrored, and then glued.
If put on proper position, the halves should weight about 140gr with the minimum support possible.

The mask models should be 210mm tall on your printing software.

Strap the elastic to the mask

There's an orifice below the eyeball due a design error, but luckily (Cthulhu's plans are
ineffable) had a purpose. Pass thru some elastic band (20mm fabric) and staple on a little loop. That's it. Just pull the band and it will hide below the eye.

Update! Clear coating and Glowing Eyes

I've found a fine company in my city https://www.fotoluminiscente.es that adviced the most efficent way to make the Master's gaze alive (Base, Paint and Coat even!) (no innocent were harmed, what a pity!)

Also I used acrylic coat to the other parts of the mask, just to give him a bath on R'Lyeh sea

Get your head 3d Scanned

Yep!, I've used a Kinect sensor and some free software to get my head into the computer

Use some Zbrush magic to design the mask on your face!

Umm.. It's a kind of black magic! (tm)

description.text:
These are the files for 4x3 Keypad, No need for flexible material, I printed with PLA. The keys must be printed separately. The Keypad electronic files schematic and PCB are attached herewith, you'll require Proteus 7.6 to open them. In PCB you need to increase the board size and point the drill holes, it can be done manually, no editing in PCB design in required.

You can contact me if you require the solidwork files for the printables.

4X3 Keypad This is a sort of case and keys for a keypad used generally with microcontrollers. Usually the ready-made keypads are weak, and does not usually carry aesthetic value. I usually do not prefer buying ready-made products and like to build my own as per my need. This is hence an effort to develop a relatively more robust and good looking keypad for the projects we build. Good luck to the users!
Gramophone 3D

This is a stylised model of a linear accelerator, similar to a Varian iX.
It was designed to aid visualisation of treatment machine angles in the planning department of the North West Cancer Centre, Tamworth, Australia.
It also has the potential to be modified to help introduce paediatric radiation therapy patients to the treatment machine and its movements.

I created it from scratch, largely by eye so it is not a scale model. This is the first complex design I have made and there is plenty of room to improve it.
As per below, not all parts of this model were 3D printed.

Printer:

Cubicon Single 110F

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

50%

Notes:

50% fill was required to allow the screws for attaching the magnets to get enough purchase in the plastic.
Printed in ABS.
I learnt a lot about print orientation from this process!

Assembly as shown in the photos requires additional parts that are not printed:

  1. I used round magnetic latch components to faciltate posable gantry and collimating rotation.
  2. The imager components are attached with nylon nuts and bolts that I purchased. The bolts are 10mm diameter and 25mm length.
  3. The fixation of the couch to the floor turntable required glue.
Magnetic Latch parts (22mm diameter x 8mm deep) screwed into pre-printed holes in the stand and gantry Another magnet screwed and a washer in pre-printed holes keep the collimator head attached and allow it to rotate Close up showing nylon nuts and bolts allowing imager arms to be posed as desired. Bolt diameter is 10mm and holes were printed with a diameter of 10.8mm. I haven't yet attempted using a tap and die set to create 3D printed nuts and bolts.

This design was developed primarily using sketches in Fusion 360.

The void in the gantry's "accelerator structure" area aimed to help the model balance and cut down on materials. Other holes have been included in the design to aid easy fixation of screws or to minimise the chance of splitting when parts were screwed on.

The stand and floor were too large to print as a single object, hence the jigsaw cut. The turntable uses hard stops to avoid the couch rotating beyond the 180 degree limits achievable in real life. Other rotations have no hard stops in this design.

comments.text: Any suggestion on where to get the magnets?
comments.author: lucserre

comments.text:
I purchased the magnets at Bunnings (Australian Hardware store). Other hardware stores should have them too. For the gantry and stand I used these particular magnets
https://www.bunnings.com.au/delf-22-x-8mm-concealed-magnetic-latch_p4010466
For the collimator I only used a single magnet attached to the gantry and an iron washer attached to the collimator.
Those magnets are surprisingly strong so be careful when you are working with them.

description.text:
Parts to mount a dial indicator to the UM2 head for precise leveling

Using a feeler gauge isn't super great for leveling. Using a dial indicator is the best method so I made a mount for my cheap eBay 10mm x 0.01mm indicator. It mounts on the front right print head screw and is very effective for bed leveling. Its designed in such a way that it just does not hit the printer during the levelling process but lift the probe as it moves.

Simple yet incredibly useful

title: Caddy 3 Disks  3,5" for NAS personal project

description.text:
Supports de disque dur 3,5"
pour un projet de NAS xpenology

J'utilise pour ce faire, un boitier HP storageworks prévu a l'origine pour accueillir 4 disques SCSI.
J'ai installé a l'intérieur une carte mère, une alimentation Standard.
les support de disques prenais trop de place pour seulement 4 disques.
Désirant monter 12 disques durs (le projet xpenology permet de simuler un SYNOLOGY DS3615xs) j'ai créer des supports de disques modulaires réunis par tranche de 3, ventilés.
Aucune vis n'est requise, les disques durs sont juste insérés dans les support et coiffés par le capot de ventilation.

Il faut imprimer 3 supports de disques et un capot de ventilation.

Les trous de fixations du ventilateur ne sont pas crées afin de vous laisser toute latitude pour le modèle de ventilateur.

description.text:
• If you made this thing and are happy with it I kindly ask to give it a shout!

==================================================================
Although yet another mobile stand I think it is kind of special and may be of use for one or the other.
Initially I made a crude proof of concept model.
It´s sound was that impressive that my wife at once nagged me into making a useable one for her iPhone 6S.
Not that she had to nag that much, I would have done that anyway......
Besides the speaker the stand is equipped with a conduit for the cable.
Although the sleeve of some accessory cables may be slightly bigger in diameter, they too, will fit well after trimming a little with a hobby-knife.
The original one fits pefectly well, even with some give to fix it with some melting-glue if wanted....
The side benefit will be, that after giving this stand to your wife, the WAF* for your printer will go through the roof :-)

I am pretty sure there will come some more models for different mobile types, but for the moment I made good experience by scaling the actual one in the slicer for my Galaxy S6.
The cut-out for the mobile is 8x68mm. For different mobiles you just have to scale the X and Y axis. Scale the Z axis the same as X to keep the circles round.

  • WAF = Wife Acceptance Factor
    For the iPhone7 one might check on http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1845365

author: plexer

description.text:
You're done with Bed Leveling Wizards, Heat-maps and Z-Probes? (but somehow your bed still isn't leveled nicely)

Alright then here is a more down-to-earth approach:

  1. Print the smallest Leveling Star (100mm)---> the first one or two layers are enough <---
    -> while printing inspect the print:

    • Where does it stick well to the bed? Where not?

    • Is the first layer on some side more transparent/thinner?

      ===> The conclusions of course are:

      • if the first layer is very transparent the bed is too high and needs to be lowerded there
      • if the first layer doesn't stick to the bed at all, the bed is probably to low and needs to be raised there
      • If you are clueless how to adjust: go for trial and error, change something -> checkout the effect

  2. Adjust your bed heights based on your observations of the print.

  3. Print the star again and check if things got better. Hopefully you see a difference to the first print and are able to adjust the bed again now based on the tremendous experience of printing two stars and seeing the effect of your adjustments.

  4. Print and adjust until you are happy with the result.

  5. Alright now move on to the next star (150mm) and keep that print'n'adjust-flow up and running ;)

  6. As soon as you are happy with the result (this will be quicker from star to start since you gain experience and only need to make small adjustments after the smaller stars printed well) you step on to the next bigger start and restart that "print'n'adjust" again.

  7. At some point you might experience (if you have a delta printer) that the bed seems to be concave or convex (in the center of the plate the print-thickness is very good, but towards the ends of the beams of the star become thinner and thinner or thicker and thicker, so the bed height in the center seemes to be ok, and to too high or too low on the outer sides). And when I tried to calibrate my delta i was like "damnit this 5mm glass plate is bend??".But of course it is not...it's calibration problem as well, but this time it is within the software.
    While the geometries of a delta bot are beautiful and interesting, sadly they are kinda complex and sometimes delicate.

    Long story short: You have to adjust the "Horizontal radius when centered" (ROD_RADIUS) parameter in the firmware. (IMPORTANT: After changing this value you have to delete the eeprom of your printer before uploading the new firmware with the adjusted value. Otherwise you will see no effect.) Since this parameter is hard to measure on a built delta bot you easily get some mm of error and this error makes the movement of the convex or concave.

    So what to do?

    • Bed concave (first layer-> ok in center, thin on the outside): increase ROD_RADIUS parameter

    • Bed convex (first layer-> ok in center, thicker/ not sticking on the outside): decrease ROD_RADIUS parameter

      (I am sorry if I confused the convex/concave decrease/increase thing. If you changed the value and it became worse just try the opposite adjustment)

  8. Adjust the parameter based on the observations of the print.

  9. Print the star again and check if things got better, readjust parameter, until you are happy with the result

  10. Step on to the next bigger star, and start printing and adjusting...

  11. Repeat until the first layer sticks on the entire bed nicely and has the same thickness everywhere :)

(scad file included so you can generate a star that fits your printer perfectly. Just adjust the "dia" and the "nrOfArms" values.)

title: Lattice Cube
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Update 16-1--16
Added a smaller version with 15mm cubes for smaller printers.
All of the lattices are 3mm diameter.

UPDATE: Updated both models with the correct orientation for printing and added filet to bottom of bases.
Also enlarged and flared the base of the large cube for better stability and bed adhesion.

This thing was inspired by Makers Muse YT stream https://youtu.be/gfbK-orCIAY
Angus does a ton of extremely helpful videos on 3D printing.

This was my first real effort with Fusion 360, I've been dabbling with it for a week or so and was looking for ideas, then Makers Muse gave me the perfect challenge.
As you can see from the third pic, the big one came off the bed after 5 hours of printing ... should have used a skirt. Argh!
So I designed a smaller version which printed perfectly.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Original Prusa i3 MK2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3 and 1.6

Infill:

20% for the base, none for the rest.

Notes:

The large cube was printed @ 0.3 layer height just to check it would print ok.
The small one was printed @ 0.16 layer height
Both models had 20 infill for the base and none for the rest.

comments.text: This will be my first print to test the printer. Any advice welcome.
comments.author: sparps

comments.text:
Hi Sparps, I wish you luck mate, let me know how it goes,
As for tips, ensure your printer is tuned right, especially the extrusion multiplier. Otherwise it could cause the thin rods to get caught on the hotend and snap off.
You could use 'Z lift' That willl make the hot end raise slightly between moves, it can help to avoid the hotend hitting the print when crossing between parts of the print.

title: Hidden Electronics Conversion Kit for MendelMax

description.text:
Before I started building a MendelMax Reprap, I laid out all of the components in CAD.  I couldn't decide how to neatly mount all of the electronics until I realized there was all that space inside the base of the frame.  So, I dreamed up these "lifters" along with split Y-Rod mounts (thing:16019) and here we are.  This allows you to "hide" your power supplier and electronics.
Since I had to move the drive system to the outside of the rods, my concern was the rigidity about the Z-axis.  I've since put about 20 hours of printing on this (4.5 hours for the longest print) and have seen no issues.

• Print 2 of each type of "lifter" and 2 belt clamps.
  • Press M3 nuts into the "lifters" (x16)
  • Install LM8UU's and internal snap rings (I used 5/16")
  • Split your Y-rods with thing:16019
  • Slide "lifters" onto rods and attach belt
  • Secure a piece of wood to your base (I used 1/4" Baltic Birch)
  • Mount electronics (designed for switching power supply, regular PC PSU's are too tall) I used wood screws for my board and wire clamps. Then liquid nails for the power supply. Ensure that "lifters" won't hit any wires when sliding.
  • Make a "mount plate" (note the countersunk holes, again I used 1/4" Baltic Birch)
  • Attach "mount plate" to "lifters with flat head bolts (x16)
  • Mount your heat bed however you'd like. My stack-up is mount plate -> heat bed -> AL plate -> glass.
  • Enjoy!

They're made for a 12V source and have a 3M tape backing that makes it really easy to install anywhere.

author: geraldstevens

description.text:
See Onshape document for more formats and if you'd like to make edits: https://cad.onshape.com/documents/26237166662ce83c328a03c7/w/02543041f83af67ffa2f3ca9/e/da9544e602f9e57c22688a11 (V3 corresponds to the version in onshape; I have not published earlier versions on Thingiverse)

This plate can be milled much thicker than the original plate; I used 3/16" (almost 5mm) thick 6061 aluminum and got good results, while still being able to move it with the original motor. The triangles are for mass reduction, and the rectangle for balance (since there are two SC8UU blocks on that side). M4 holes are oversize as on original, to allow for some error in rod spacing.

This plate supports 3-point leveling, and the screws clear the frame as placed. I can't do 3-point leveling on the front/rear edges without modifying the frame.

Photos soon!

title: organic and low poly styled bow-tie

description.text:
This is a pretty organic and low poly styled bow-tie and pocket assortement for your suit. They are completely usable for your parties.

I create this one for my brother marriage!

The idea of this design is to broke the symetry of the standard bow-tie. Also Ì wanted to create a real contrast in the structure, to do it I unsing organic and low poly style together.

I create it using 3dsmax, Onshape, and meshmixer.
You will need to have 2x"M3 with cone head screw" and a low cost real bow-tie for the neckline.
The fix.stl part is used to keep up the neckline on the bow-tie.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

low - medium

Notes:

I print the main part back face to the floor.
Watch out, if your support structure is too heavy you will have many difficulties to remove it, if your support structure is too light you will have a poor aspect on the back of your bow-tie.

After printing i sand down it and paint it.

print_settings.Infill:: around 15% could be 20 depending on strength wanted

description.text: Since I began to grow tired of carrying my heavy tenor saxophone case, I decided to make wheels for the case. It took five tries to get a fully function version. I hope you enjoy!

Printer:

XYZ Printing Da Vinci Jr. 1.0

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.4

Infill:

around 15% could be 20 depending on strength wanted

Notes:

At first I was printing the wheels at 15% infill, but I recently dropped the wheels and the wheels snapped right down the middle so I recommend using 20%.

Gluing and Wheels

In order to attach the left and right side of the wheels you will need to glue the two sections together along with a metal bracket in the middle. Just to make it look better I wrapped electrical tape around the bracket as you can do too. After you are done gluing you will need to drill a small hole in the axle to screw in the cap to hold the wheel in place. When you are done with that place the wheel on the axle and find a screw to put in the cap and screw in the axle. When you are done with that you have officially finished putting together the wheels.

Numbers and Rotation

Before you print make sure to rotate the files on you print software to fit the specifications of you printer (rotate so it can print as well as possible). Also print two wheels and two caps for the axles to complete the wheels.

90 degree angle.

title: Air Hockey Robot EVO (SMARTPHONE CONTROLLED - OPEN SOURCE ROBOT)

description.text:
The new Air Hockey Robot EVO. Perfect to learn about Robotics, visual recognition,behavioural robotics (and have fun!)

Based on our first Air Hockey Robot, this new Air Hockey Robot EVO is much easier to set-up and deploy. Now, controlled by your own smartphone using the freely available APP (the APP will let you control the robot manually too)

A challenging robot, perfect to have fun and learn robotics at the same time

This EVO version is faster, easily modifiable and shares the electronics and ancillary elements with others jjRobots like the iBoardbot , B-robot EVO, Sphere-O-bot, (and more to come!)

We have based this new design on the standard parts of a typical 3D printer, such as the NEMA 17 stepper motors, the jjRobots Brain Shield,belts, bearings and rods.

We have opted to use a medium-sized air hockey table with dimensions of 80 x 42 cm (31.5 x 16.5 in) and a two-motor X-Y movement design (H-bot), with both motors working at the same time, moving the robot up/down and left/right. Simple but ...cool

  • Get everything (all the hardware) with the AIR HOCKEY ROBOT EVO KIT
  • Air Hockey Robot main page (MUCH MORE INFO): http://www.jjrobots.com/air-hockey-robot-evo/
  • Assembly guide:(with tons of photos and videos) http://www.jjrobots.com/air-hockey-robot-evo-assembly-guide-v-1-2/
  • Community: http://jjrobots.com/forum/forum-4.html
  • Youtube video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lZmp9elPgKo

ELEMENTS TO BE PRINTED:

6X 623 PULLEY
2x BUSHING
1X POLE SUPPORT BASE
1X SMARTPHONE SUPPORT TOP
2X FAN SUPPORT
2X LATERAL SLIDER
2X LATERAL SUPPORT
1X MOTOR HOLDER RIGHT
1X MOTOR HOLDER LEFT
2X MOTOR PULLEY
1X ROBOT PUSHER
1x ROBOT PUSHER BASE
1x PUCK (optional but recommended. This puck improves the game speed)

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Resolution:

0.20

Infill:

35

Notes:

PLA works perfectly.

NOTE: Do not use BLUE or GREEN to print the 3D parts.
The reason: the robot is always looking for BLUE and GREEN features on the playing court in order to detect the PUCK and the PUSHER.
NOTE: Print the PUCK with support. Then, remove it.
Recommended Filament colours : BLACK/RED or WHITE
NGSS CCSS

Your smartphone will become an augmented reality device, showing predicted trajectories and position of all the objects involved in this game. The smartphone´s camera (2) looks at the playing court . The captured data is processed in real time by the smartphone. After detecting the position of the puck and the “Pusher robot” (and according to the current location of all the elements on the court), your smartphone makes decisions and commands the Robot (3) via WIFI (1). The Robot is locally controlled by the jjRobots Brain Shield (1) which dictates the speed and acceleration of the robot, sending the appropriate pulses to the stepper motors. Easy! (but, a video explain everything better than a text: check the youtube video linked above )

Robot features:
  • Fun robot
  • 100% OPEN SOURCE robot
  • Featuring a powerful visual detection system
  • Learn How to send data via WIFI between a smartphone and your robot
  • Learn how to modify it for your own purposes using your own CAD software (you can create a larger version as a challenge)
  • Concepts of Physics: Friction, continuous and uniform motion, rebounds, concepts of position, speed and acceleration
  • Mathematical Concepts: Equation of the line through two points, prediction, XY Cartesian System
  • Robotics: control Motors, Vision, PID Control, Arduino programming
  • Hacking: Using 3D printer parts to build something completely different (bigger air hockey robot?).

BILL OF MATERIALS 12x M3 bolt 6mm
4x M3 bolt 10mm
6x M3 bolt 15mm
4x M3 bolt 20 mm
16x M3 nut
2x M3 self blocking nut
10x M2.5 Wood screw 20mm
EVA FOAM (two different colours)
4cm 12V FAN
2x Stepper motor NEMA17 + cables (70+70 cms)
jjRobots Brain Shield
Arduino Leonardo
2x Stepper motor drivers (DRV8825 or A4988) + heatsinks
12V 2A power supply 5.5mm 2.5mm jack
2x LM88UU linear ball bearing
12x 623 ball bearings
2x Stainless steel bar 8⌀ 455mm long
2x Anodised aluminium tube 8⌀ 435 mm long
1x Aluminium square pipe 12×12 mm
GT2 timing belt (300 cm)
6x zip ties (150mm x 3 mm)
double side sticky foam
*smartphone holder´s bolt Get everything with the AIR HOCKEY ROBOT EVO KIT NOTE If you have created a B-robot EVO, the iBoardbot or the Sphere-O-bot,, you already have the electronics and almost all the ancillary elements to create your Air Hockey Robot EVO Air Hockey Robot Kit: elements

• robotics
  • electronics
  • arduino
  • visual recognition
  • robotic vision
  • PID control
  • basic mechanics
